Rear Window Review
The film Rear Window is about a photographer named Jeff. Jeff has a broken leg and is stuck in his apartment for another week. So, what does he do? He looks out the window and watches his neighbors. When one of his neighbors starts acting suspicions Jeff starts to think that he murdered his wife. Jeff's girlfriend Lisa, and his nurse Stella also become suspicious and they investigate. 
Rear Window is a fantastic film filled with suspense and excitement. There are some amazing techniques used in in the film. Starting with the control of your emotions right from the start. After only a few minutes into the film we learn of Jeff's suspicions of the neighbor Mr. Thorwald. The suspense and my curiosity only went up from there. This control from the start had completely blew my expectations out of the water. I thought I was going to half pay attention, half do something else, but I couldn't. I was fully focused and engaged in the film right from the start. 
Besides grabbing you from the start there are many great technical effects used in the making of this film. For example, we go through the story from Jeff's perspective. We see what is happening as Jeff does. He is looking out his window across the courtyard at his neighbor's apartment. We see this as a wide shot. The audience sees what Jeff sees. We also look through his hand-held camera with him to zoom in across the courtyard. Another way we share Jeff's perspective is by viewing the events in the film through his eyes. There is a moving shot following Jeff's eyes looking through the courtyard. The camera also pans from inside the apartment to outside and to the neighbor's apartments following where Jeff is looking. 
Other great effects in the film are the sound. I think the most dramatic example is when Mr. Thorwald is walking towards Jeff's apartment. You can hear his footsteps, one at a time, slowly waking towards the door, getting louder and closer. This add suspense. Another key element to the sound in the film was the music. Music helps to show what is going in a story. Suspenseful music enhances suspenseful scenes and intensifies the viewers experience. This also helps to control our emotions. 
Rear window has some interesting ideas for characterization. These ideas are conveyed through the characters names, dialogue and actions. The two main characters are Jeff and Lisa. Jeff is an average name for an average person with an average life and job. Lisa has a pretty name which is appropriate to her character. In the film she is a beautiful fasion model. We don't always associate intelligence with someone who appears as Lisa does but she is much more than that, and we see this through her words and actions. Towards the beginning of the film and through ought its entirety Lisa believes that Mr. Thorwald did murder his wife because she would have never left the house without her purse, wedding ring and other jewelry. Lisa calls this her women's intuition. We also learn more about her character through her actions. Towards the end of the film she goes across the court yard and climbs up the fire escape to Mr. Thorwald's apartment. This demonstrates that she is much more than a pretty model. It demonstrates that she has courage and bravery. 
Lastly Alfred Hitchcock is great with lighting and its effect on the story. As we follow Jeff we learn more information as he does. To elaborate, we learn more about Thorwald in the day time then at night. At night Jeff is just guessing and speculation about what is going on. All this appropriately matches up with the amount of lighting that is in the scene. 
I understand why this film is considered a classic and would recommend it to others.

title: Audiovisual masterpiece
review:
Being a Hitchcock movie, Rear Window has excellent use of many tactics to increase suspense. One thing that I found fascinating was how this film also skillfully employs the use of audio and the view of the camera in playing with the concept of perspective. Jefferies is physically trapped in his apartment, bound by injury and feels trapped emotionally as well. We are kept inside the apartment with him until Jefferies finally "makes his exit". Throughout the whole film what we are able to hear is true to what Jefferies would have been able to hear except at a couple key points. 
When Jeff is in his apartment listening out he can hardly make out what people are saying, at several points in the movie he often leans in to try and hear better, an action that is accompanied by slight tightening of the camera shots, which really creates a very accurate first-person perspective. Hitchcock tried very hard to keep the perspective true to what those looking out of the window were seeing, only using third person shots within the apartment and in the final scenes. This was important because, by trapping us in one perspective, some information seemed desperately close but still out of reach, creating Hitchcock's favorite thing, suspense. However, that is not the only reason the use of perspective was critical in this film. It was important because whenever it was strayed from an event would stand out drastically. Look, for example, at when the footsteps were coming up the hall at the beginning of the third act, they were by far the loudest thing to happen in the movie up to that point, which brought a new element into the film, fear. Up till then we had felt safe yet quizzical in Jefferies' apartment, trying to figure out a puzzle on the outside. Now that puzzle and all the dangers with it, were coming into our safe space where we had been trapped. The sheer difference in the exaggerated volume (along with the lighting of the apartment) this scene had from those before made it stand out and added emotion. 
Another example of how perspective was used in the film is rooted in the camerawork rather than the audio. As I stated before, the only time the camera shot leaves the apartment is when Jefferies does. Once he is outside the apartment we see the scene from the perspective of the onlookers and those in the apartment. This is in stark contrast to the views we have had up to this point and lends additional gravity to an already heavy scene. Finally, by trapping the camera in the apartment Hitchcock was able to also make my favorite scene in the movie. When Lisa was in Thorwald's apartment we could see her actions along with Thorwald's walk up the hall at the same time. This created an intensely suspenseful scene having all the aspects of parallel editing without the camera ever having to change its location.
Hitchcock was known for his use of suspense and Rear Window is another suspenseful masterpiece. There were a number of other very intriguing facets to this movie but what really stood out to me was his ability to create suspense and manipulate his audience with perspective. This film was a delight to watch and there is much more to be said about it but I didn't see much mention of Hitchcock's use of audiovisual in the reviews, so I thought I would bring up my perspective.

title: Very good movie
review:
Alfred Hitchcock's Rear Window is a masterpiece of filmmaking. The film focuses on a professional photographer, Jeff Jeffries, who broke his leg and spends his time recovering by looking at his neighbors through a rear window in his apartment. Throughout this time Jeff suspects that one of his neighbors has murdered someone, while also having conflicts with his girlfriend, Lisa Fremont. 
 Throughout the film, there is a linear plot. This helps ensure that the audience is not bored while watching the film, as there is always something new happening throughout the film. This plot does focus on a specific point, which is the lives of Jeff's neighbors. The entire plot occurs within one setting, which is Jeff's apartment. Nevertheless, through Hitchcock's change throughout the film, audience remains entertained despite the fact that the setting does not change throughout the film, which is something that was not really done at the time. 
 Hitchcock's use of conflict also works towards the goal of entertaining the audience. The film does delve into aspects of the lives of the other characters, but maintains a focus on Jeff Jefferies, the film's main character. The struggles shown throughout the film are his own, from the internal conflict of whether to marry Lisa Fremont, to the external conflict of proving Thorwald murdered his wife. These conflicts are developed in a way that holds the viewer's interest.
 The film's use of suspense also helps keep the audience interested. Throughout the entire film, Hitchcock never actually shows that Lars Thorwald murdered his wife, but the audience is informed of Jeff's suspicions as Lar's actions get more and more dubious throughout the course of the film. The audience is left with the question of whether Jeff will be proven wrong, or if Thorwald really did murder his wife, throughout the entire Second Act. of the film. Hitchcock also uses suspense in smaller magnitudes throughout the film, including a phone call that Detective Doyle takes. The audience doesn't hear the call after the caller asks if Doyle is on the line, but we are told of it afterwards. In the meantime, we are left wondering what was said and what effect it would have on the film. This furthers the audience's interest and renders them unable to stop watching. 
 Hitchcock presents moral questions regarding privacy throughout the film, which is one of the central themes. Throughout the entire film, Jeffries's curiosity leads him to invade his neighbors lives from afar, and take the audience along with him. It even gets to the point where he almost takes his focus off of a woman about to commit suicide in order to satisfy his curiosity about whether Thorwald killed his wife or not, but it doesn't end there. Jeffries continuously spies on all of his neighbors, coming up with cute names for them. He spends his entire recovery looking out of a rear window at his neighbors. He is literally unable to stop. This point is stressed by the actors in the film, where the actor portraying Jeff shows that there is no point where Jeff will not go in order to satisfy the urge to spy on his neighbors. When the lights in Thorwald's apartment goes out, he simply changes to a different neighbor for a moment. This central theme of the ethics of questions regarding breaching someone's privacy adds to the content of the film, making it substantially more interesting. 
 Hitchcock also uses irony beautifully in Rear Window. Throughout the entire film, all Jeff wants is to go back to work and get out of his apartment. He even asks for a job while he is still in a cast, which he is denied. In the end he ends up with another broken leg. This further adds to the theme of the ethics involving privacy because it almost seems to be a punishment to Jeff for spying on his neighbors so frequently. Now he will have to stay in his apartment for much longer than he intended, which he considered torture. 
 The script of Rear Window is written well in order to convey the theme and maintain the audience's interest. Throughout the movie, there is always some element at play maintains the viewers' interest in the film, and the plot furthers the central theme. Whether it's irony, suspense, or action, there is always something holding the attention of the audience. Alfred Hitchcock's Rear Window manages to experiment and break norms of the time in order to deliver a wonderful experience to the audience, and is interesting at every turn.

title: Rear Window
review: Alfred Hitchcock's Rear Window is a very captivating piece. In the film a professional traveling photographer, L. B. Jefferies, is confined to his small apartment due to a broken leg. He becomes infatuated with watching the everyday lives of his neighbors through his window. As time goes on, Jefferies starts to believe that he may have witnessed a murder of a woman take place in one of the apartments due to the suspicious actions taken by his neighbor, Thorwald. Jefferies tries to piece together this mystery while also trying to gain the help of his girlfriend Lisa, his nurse Stella, and detective and friend, Doyle. The tension and excitement in the film becomes so exquisite that the viewer tends to forget a very large piece of the film; Jefferies never leaves his room. The entire movie is set from Jefferies' apartment. We become so involved with the story and concerned over what is going to happen next, we don't even realize the setting is the same throughout the entirety of the film. The camera angles also help us with this. We feel as though we are also watching Jefferies' neighbors through his window, as if we were sitting in the room right there with Jefferies. We understand his point of view very well because he is unable to leave his room due to his broken leg. All the characters in this film, including Lisa and Stella, leave Jefferies' apartment at some point, but as for us, the camera stays in the room for the entire time, so we only see through Jefferies' view. To add to the mysterious vibe of the film, we are only able to see some parts of what happens across the way. For example, when Lisa goes into the murder's, Thorwald's, apartment, we are only able to see half of what is going on. Some scenes are cut off by a wall or a building to add to the suspense of the scene. Another element that makes this plot so interesting is how Jefferies' perspective on love and marriage changed throughout the film. As he watches through his window, he sees people in many different stages of their relationships. He starts out not wanting to marry Lisa. As the film progresses and he continues to observe these couples and fall more in love with Lisa, he realizes that he wants to be with her for the rest of his life. This was a very subtle, yet delightful, addition to the plot of the film. Another important element that makes this film so enticing is the plot progression. The plot includes the linear structure of films in acts broken down into exposition, complication, climax, and denouement. Throughout the film, Jefferies' is made out to be crazy by his friend Doyle. Doyle is a detective and every time Jefferies has a claim against Thorwald, Doyle is there to automatically shut it down. But with the help of Lisa and Stella, Jefferies eventually proves that he was right all along, and all the pieces come together. In the beginning of the film, the mood starts off very laidback and innocent, but as it progresses, we start to see how serious the problem really is and eventually Jefferies is caught right up in the action. It is definitely a film that will keep you interested throughout due to all of the suspense. This movie shows the overall nature of humans; we are very curious beings. As for the ending, we are aware of what Thorwald can do, which makes this scene so suspenseful. But, due to Jefferies' fast and resourceful thinking he is able to survive the attack and Thorwald is finally caught for the vicious crime he has committed. This is one of the most remarkable and gripping endings I have ever watched. Rear Window by Alfred Hitchcock aged very well and is definitely still a must-see.

title: One of Hitchcock's Classics
review:
Hitchcock's Rear Window is a masterpiece that pairs dynamic cinematography and sound design with great acting and a unique plot. The film is highly experimental, with every scene being shot on a single (but massive) soundstage; and with most of the scenes being shot from one camera location within that soundstage. The title is very apt, as we experience almost the entire film through the rear window of a Chelsea apartment. Despite these self imposed restrictions, the film is still able to captivate audiences to this day.

In the expository phase of the film, we learn much about the protagonist L.B. 'Jeff' Jeffries from the very first shot. We see out the window from which he looks, all of his neighbors going about their daily business, generally a very vibrant and lively opening scene. Then, as the camera pans inward towards Jeffries' apartment, the film gives us an overview of his condition, by showing us the cast of his broken leg, his name, by showing us the writing on the cast, his job, by showing us some of his photography, and his girlfriend, by showing us a picture of her; all without a single word being spoken. Most of the shots at the beginning of each scene are remarkable because of the camera's range of movement; panning and tilting extreme angles. Another bulletin of the cinematography in Rear Window is the heavy use of perspective changes. While we are inside the apartment itself, the cameras take on a more traditional objective perspective, placing the audience as the third party. However, when Jeffries is looking out the window, we subjectively see what he sees, and this is done in a very realistic way. When Jeffries looks towards something that is far away, the scene is not artificially close to the subject of the camera. Instead, we see a wide shot and, as if we were looking out the rear window ourselves, it is hard to completely make out everything that is happening. Of course, when Jeffries picks up a pair of binoculars or a camera, we are able to see a more clear picture of what is happening. This is also reflected in the sound design, as we cannot totally hear everything from a distance and have to try and make out what is being said.

In the opening scene, we are introduced to Jeffries' employer over the phone: they talk about his potential new assignment, going to Indo-China and photographing the situation there. When we are introduced to Stella (Jeffries' nurse) in the next scene, she brings up how she predicted the stock market crash of 1929. These remarks serve to add dimensionality to their characters and make them more relatable to the audience of the time. We are then introduced to Jeffries' neighbors: a newlywed couple, a lonely pianist, a girl nicknamed Miss Lonelyhearts, a seemingly single ballet dancer nicknamed Miss Torso, a sculptor, a couple and their dog, and Thorwald and his wife. The obvious theme presented to us is one of relationships at their various stages: this transitions us well into the overarching conflict between Jeffries and his girlfriend Lisa Freemont. Jeffries and Freemont both work for magazines, but the nature of their work is very different. Jeffries is a photographer who travels the world in pursuit of the latest global conflicts and stories while Lisa is an editor and model for a New York fashion magazine. Lisa would like nothing more but for Jeff to settle down with her and get married, while Jeff would like nothing more but to continue his world travels. Jeff, while still loving her, believes that Lisa is too sophisticated to be his wife, and our first impression of her supports this view. Lisa thinks Jeff is wrong and wants to prove that she is up to the task of world exploration.

The next scene brings us to the main conflict phase of the film. On a rainy night in the early hours of the morning, Jeffries hears a woman scream "Don't!" followed by the shattering of a glass. Then, he sees his neighbor Thorwald carry a briefcase several times from his apartment to an undisclosed location. The next morning we see Thorwald cleaning off a knife and saw blade and wrapping them with newspaper. At this point the connotation is obvious and need not be stated until Lisa returns the next day. She sees an opportunity in this case, however grim it may be, to prove her worth to Jeffries. After unsuccessfully trying to get his detective friend to investigate and prosecute Thorwald, Jeffries decides to take things into his own hands. Jeffries sends Lisa to slide a note under Thorwald's door to elicit a reaction and succeeds in not getting caught. Later, however, when Stella and Lisa go to investigate Thorwald's flower bed for evidence and come up blank, Lisa runs and quickly climbs the fire escape to enter Thorwald's apartment.

What follows is both the climax of the plot and a classic Hitchcock suspense scene that lasts until almost the end of the film. Jeff wants to call Thorwald's apartment to get Lisa out of there but gets distracted by Miss Lonelyhearts' attempt at suicide. In a hint of dramatic irony, the audience is completely aware of Jeff and Stella's ignorance and expects Thorwald's sudden return. When the police enter Thorwald's apartment they prevent him from attacking Lisa further, but Thorwald then realizes he is being watched by Jeffries. Stella leaves to bail out Lisa, and minutes after, Jeffries receives a call: it's Thorwald. After a brief pause to let it sink in, we hear a door slam in the distance. The footsteps approach closer and closer, the light in the hall goes out. When Thorwald enters, the only light source shines on his face. Upon realizing that Jeffries has made the police aware of the murder, Thorwald begins to approach but is hindered by Jeffries use of flashbulbs. The camera takes on the perspective of Thorwald, and visual effects are used to illustrate his temporary blindness after the use of each bulb. When Thorwald does finally reach Jeffries, a close up action scene ensues, with Thorwald throwing Jeffries out of the window from which he was watched. This is the only scene when the camera exited the apartment. In the end, the police arrive again just in time to break Jeffries fall and arrest Thorwald.

Directly after the climax ends and justice is served, we are presented with a scene very similar to the beginning of the film, although this time all of the minor conflicts of the plot are resolved as well: the Pianist and Miss Lonelyhearts are now a couple, the neighbors got a new dog, Miss Torso's boyfriend returns from the army, and Lisa appears to have taken an interest in exploration as she is reading 'Beyond the Himalayas' (although she appears to switch over to a fashion magazine when she realizes Jeffries is asleep). Overall, the film is remarkable in its use of dynamic cinematography from a static setting, and its use of the first person perspective to really make the audience of the film feel directly involved. The characters are well thought out and relatable, and the plot works very well despite the restrictions. Rear Window is a clear exemplification of Hitchcock's natural aptitude for cinematography, plot, and suspense.

title: Innovative engagement of the audience
review:
Rear Window is a fantastic mystery and suspense film utilizing unique techniques to captivate the audience. Alfred Hitchcock uses phenomenal camera placement and carefully positioned shots to connect the audience to the main character in a special way. The eyes of the main character, Jefferies, are almost directly tied to what the audience sees. The entire setting for the movie is within Jeff's apartment and the view outside of the window, yet the camera placement is so effective that this setting constraint goes practically unnoticed. With added elements of suspense and such a limited camera viewpoint, the audience is left on the edge of their seats wanting to see what simply can't be seen. 
For a vast majority of the film, the camera is fixated in the apartment of Jefferies and never shows anything beyond the perspective of Jeff himself. Jeff was injured trying to take an action shot on a racetrack, leaving him immobile in a wheelchair next to his apartment window. He spends hours gazing out the window, watching his neighbors, to pass the time. The camera positioning resembles Jeff's view outside the window, panning across the windows just as if Jeff's head was turning. Whenever Jeff leans in to try and get a better view, the next shot is zoomed in a little closer to reflect it. This makes the audience feel extremely connected with Jeff, what he sees is what the audience sees. As Jeff looks around at his neighbors, the audience gets to know the characters, but only from the point of view from which Jeff can see. Conversations can be seen in windows between couples, yet Jeff is too far away to hear and therefore the audience can't hear. The curiosity of Jeff is almost directly passed onto the audience, who struggles to understand the surroundings just as much as he does. This is proven to be very effective once Jeff notices strange behaviours from his neighbor Mr. Thorwald. Jeff can only see snippets of Thorwald's suspicious actions, and they suggest that Thorwald has murdered his wife. He spends hours stalking the man from the window, trying to uncover the mystery as best he can from his viewpoint. The audience is left completely in the dark, only able to see what Jeff can see, escalating the mystery of the murder. The connection of the camera to Jeff's viewpoint captivates the audience in such a unique way.
With the camera being tied to Jeff, the setting for the film almost never changes. Jeff is stuck with a cast on his leg, leaving him in a wheelchair in his apartment. He can't leave the apartment and struggles to move around the room. As a result, the entire setting of the film is limited to the main room of the apartment and its window view. Despite this, the setting limitation goes almost unnoticed. Jeff constantly has visitors or phone calls that give the audience insight into the outside world, never truly limiting the plot to the setting. It is quite impressive how a long film can be so engaging and interesting to the audience, despite taking place in a single room. 
While using thoughtful camera placement to engage the audience, Alfred Hitchcock takes it one step further with suspense. The most noticeable suspense scene takes place right at the climax of the film, when Thorwald breaks into Jeff's apartment. The scene begins with a phone call that Jeff answers, thinking it's his friend. He starts talking immediately, only to be met with cold silence followed by the click of the line ending. Footsteps are then heard in the distance, slowly approaching the door of the apartment. With the lights in the apartment off, the shadow of a man can clearly be seen stop directly in front of the door and pause. Throughout this scene, Jeff is frantically trying to move about the room in his wheelchair, but with little success. With the camera stuck in the room, the audience feels trapped with nowhere to go just watching the main character panic. Once Thorwald breaks into the apartment, it is almost as if he broke into the audience's personal space. The audience has safely watched the story unfold up in Jeff's apartment, only to find the murderer directly in their viewpoint. This suspense and shock grabs the audience for the duration of the climax, making it one of the most engaging parts of the film. By using innovative camera positioning and implementing suspenseful scenes, Alfred Hitchcock creates one of the most engaging and suspenseful films to watch.

title: Rear Window Review
review:
Alfred Hitchcock is undoubtedly the master of suspense. "Rear Window" is a testament to his ability to keep viewers on the edge of their seats. Not only does he build suspense through the power of doubt, but the subtleties of his camera-work contribute to the audience's physical and emotional investment.

Rear Window's main character, Jeff, is wheelchair bound after having broken his leg. He spends his time spying on his neighbors, who end up all representing different aspects of love & relationships. One neighbor in particular, Mr. Thorwald, becomes especially suspicious to Jeff as his behaviors seem to indicate that he killed his wife after a rough marriage. We are introduced to Stella, Jeff's visiting nurse who is initially skeptical, and Lisa, Jeff's love interest. Both characters eventually join Jeff in his speculation, and work together trying to figure out if Mr. Thorwald really is a murderer. In the end, Mr. Thorwald is caught and Jeff falls in love with Lisa.

Like any other mystery movie, Rear Window withholds the killer's reveal until the very end, but Hitchcock takes building the suspense a step further. Throughout the movie, Hitchcock makes the audience question or even doubt Jeff, by introducing counter evidence. At times, we are made to believe that maybe Jeff's opinion's are hyper speculative and that his observations can be explained by perfectly reasonable behaviors. This doubt makes the mystery and the suspense so much more powerful, as the situation could realistically go either way. We first begin to doubt Jeff when we are introduced to Stella. Jeff tells Stella about his theory that Mr. Thorwald is a killer, and Stella very reasonably comes up with other explanations for Mr. Thorwald's actions. Hitchcock makes us doubt Jeff a second time, when we are introduced to Detective Doyle. Like Stella, Doyle explains that it is unreasonable to accuse Mr. Thorwald since there is a lack of concrete evidence, let alone act on it and search his apartment. It is hard not to side with Doyle, after all he is an experienced professional with a high reputation. The third and final time Hitchcock makes us doubt Jeff, is when Lisa sneaks into Mr. Thorwald's apartment in search of Mrs. Thorwald's ring. The trio (Jeff, Stella, and Lisa) had reasoned that Mr. Thorwald was sloppy in his execution, and had put Mrs. Thorwald's ring into her purse; a place no woman would ever keep her jewelry. The trio was sure that they would find the ring and solve the mystery. As we watch from Jeff's apartment, Lisa finds that the purse was empty and we are instantly hit with a feeling of "oh crap! Maybe we were wrong about this..." By making us doubt the characters and even ourselves to an extent, Hitchcock masterfully keeps the tension high. The audience can't help but feeling anxious that they might have been wrong, a critical element of suspense.

Hitchcock creates suspense with the plot, but he really raises tensions through his camera work. The brilliance of creating Jeff as a character in a wheelchair, excuses the anchoring of the camera throughout the movie. (In any other circumstance, the anchored camera would have made for a dull viewing experience). Instead, Hitchcock takes advantage refusing to zoom in or give us a better angle of what Mr. Thorwald is doing. So much of the movie's suspense is caused by the audience craning their necks to see what is going on in Mr. Thorwald's apartment. Hitchcock physically makes the audience lean forward and squint, just like Jeff. He even refuses to give away what Mr. Thorwald is saying, covering it up by street noise. Without even noticing it, the audience can't help but join the trio in trying to solve the mystery. This is the brilliance of Hitchcock's anchored camera.

Another masterful use of the camera is, strangely, when it is pointed away from the action. For example, when Lisa is caught by Mr. Thorwald after having snooped around his apartment, Hitchcock chooses to point the camera on Jeff and Stella's faces instead of the active conflict between Lisa and Mr. Thorwald. He refuses to let us see what's happening. We instead see the terrified looks on Jeff and Lisa's faces, and our minds begin to race as we try to imagine the horror they are looking at. Hitchcock defined suspense as the opposite of shock. Shock is caused by a sudden surprise, whereas suspense is created within the audience's own minds. It is our imagination of all the horrible possibilities that makes this technique so suspenseful.

Rear Window is a model example of how to best create suspense. Hitchcock's insertion of doubt into the plot, use of camera positioning make this movie a classic.

title: Rear Window
review:
In Alfred Hitchcock's film Rear Window, he masterly tells a story quite unusual from the rest. Mr. Hitchcock dives into the realm of observation as he portrays L.B Jefferies, a wheelchair bound photographer bored out of his mind. Jefferies, trapped in his tiny apartment, casts his view towards the outside courtyard to gaze at his neighbors. As Jefferies peers into what is best left unseen, he catches onto the coattails of what seems to be a murder. Jefferies, along with his fiancée, watch and unravel the mystery that unfolds in Jefferies' backyard.
Alfred Hitchcock is crowned to be the master of suspense and carries his title into this film. Hitchcock employs the viewers to fixate on actions done by characters to build suspense through out the film. One suspenseful scene highlighted in the film is when Mr. Thorwald catches the sight of Jefferies spying on him through the window. As Mr. Thorwald makes his way over to Jefferies, Hitchcock builds suspense by what is left unseen. The scene grows more and more intense as the deafening sounds of Throvald's foot falls approach Jefferies' door. Jefferies' actions are also used to build the suspense of the film. Jefferies answers a call from Doyle in a hurried whisper, detailing the event of what transpired that night. Another call comes in later in which Jeff answers in a hurry, believing its's Doyle. Only after the phone call cuts off after a few words from Jeff does the viewer guess at who the caller truly was. By using the reader to use their mind to guess at the true caller, Hitchcock deepens the interest of the viewer and more so the suspense. Later the suspense builds as the view watches Jefferies scramble around to prepare for the inevitable entry of Thorwald. Whether it is the actions of others left unseen or the actions that the viewer sees, both of these are employed by Hitchcock to increase the suspense of the movie.
Another device that Hitchcock uses is foreshadowing, primarily in the scenes with Stella, Jeff's nurse that takes care of him on occasion. While Jeff first exposes his interest in viewing the courtyard and spying on people, Stella comments that the punishment for a peeping tom is six months in the workhouse. Later she continues to detail that she has a nose for trouble. This trouble is what Hitchcock wants to focus on. The trouble that will continue to develop in the second act, the complication, will form all from the observations that Jeff will make in the coming days. When Jeff starts "seeing things (he) shouldn't see", he will entangle himself into the trouble brewing underneath the surface in these apartments.
Hitchcock holds a deep respect for the camera and how it can be used to tell a story. Hitchcock, in multiple scenes across the film, uses Jeff's camera or action of leaning in to zoom into certain areas. The zooming in of a camera is used to place a greater emphasis on the actions seen through those lenses. The scene that comes to mind is during Jeff's diner with Lisa. As she wanders into the kitchen to prepare the meal, Jeff can be seen looking out the window staring at the Thorwalds. Jeff is slowly gripped by the situation and hopes to learn more by leaning in which in turn zooms in the whole view of the camera. As Mr. and Mrs. Thorwald argue, Jeff desperately tries to hear more but ultimately fails, leaving the conversation left up to the viewer to piece together. Hitchcock wishes to convey to the viewer that this scene is important through the leaning and zooming in. Other important scenes also revolve around the zooming in aspect employed by Hitchcock and are highlighted due to this. 
Although Hitchcock doesn't have Jeff go into much detail on the morality of watching people, he uses other means to convey his feelings to the viewer. Hitchcock has shadows to emphasize this point. Whenever Jeff fears of being spotted, he doesn't stay by the window in the light where he can own up to his crime, instead he retreats into the darkness of the shadows behind him. The shadows casually fall down onto Jeff's face which symbolizes the darker theme of what he is doing. 
The last area that Hitchcock looks into is the sense of being an observer. Throughout the film, Jeff is trapped in his wheelchair with nowhere to go. He looks down on his neighbors and spies into their lives. However, Hitchcock uses much more to develop Jeff as an observer. During moments of action and suspense, Jeff is sometimes trapped in hesitation and much like the viewer, fail to act. As Lisa explores the apartment and Thorwald approaches, both the viewer and Jeff can do little more than hope that everything will turn out ok. It was only after a little delay that Jeff realizes that he remembers that he is also an active character that can do something to prevent a tragedy. It is in this moment that he escapes his illusion of only being an observer and becomes a player who calls the police. Hitchcock uses Jeff's identity as an observer to develop a stronger sense of connection between the viewers and Jeff, all in the name of allowing the viewers to understand and become more invested in the story. It isn't only until the end of the story that Jeff is thrust into an active role to defend himself from Thorwald's attacks.

title: A Film with Rich Informations and Textbook Techniques
review:
In the Rear Window directed by Alfred Hitchcock, the story take place in a small but at the same time a large community. In the movie, Alfred Hitchcock is discussing the topic of voyeurism, depicting the change of main characters' mindset, and detective element that deals with a murder case through the point of view of a broken leg person, Jefferies. As the nature of human, people are always curious about what is behind the curtain even though it does not do any good to them. Here, Hitchcock uses Jefferies as the perfect person to peep through windows of his neighbors. Jefferies broke his leg for 7 weeks already, and during this period of time, he keeps peeps out of his window and looks at what is his neighbors doing. This is totally legit since they did not close their windows and Jefferies don't have anything else to do besides this.
 In the exposition, Hitchcock starts with the use of an objective viewpoint to bring audiences into the setting. He quickly panning and tilting around the community so that the audiences can have a better picture of the neighborhood and Jefferies's neighbors. At this point, the audiences might be confused about why are there so many foci on this particular area. Hitchcock explains it well by emphasizing the size and closeness of Jefferies's cast. Within one minute, Hitchcock is able to use the focus of destroyed items and photographs hang on the wall to answer how did Jefferies break his leg. Lastly, before there is any dialogue happening, he gives another focus on stacks of magazines on the table with a woman as cover, labeling "Paris Fashion" at the bottom left corner. Based on previous information, the audience know that this woman has nothing to do with Jefferies's career, so why would he have so many magazines about her? It can only be either Jefferies has a strong possession to her or they have a special relationship. This creates a suspension for the audiences that they want to know what's going on with him and what is that woman's role in the play.
 During the phone call, the audiences know that Jefferies has been sitting in a wheelchair for 7 weeks and yet he still need to endure another week before he can take off his cast. While Jefferies is speaking, Hitchcock changes from an objective view to subjective view. First a scene of Jefferies looking outside of the window, and then the audiences join his view. This same step is repeated multiple time by Hitchcock later on in the movie. Through this, the audiences can follow what's going on in the neighborhood and put themselves in Jefferies' spot as a peeper. Especially when Jefferies is peeping through Thorwald's family for the first time in the film, the audiences can clearly see the difference after the cuts between objective and subjective view. That as Jefferies stretches his neck for a better view, the next subjective view of the Thorwald family will appear larger for the audiences. This technique makes the audiences feel like they are involved in the film, that they are the Jefferies.
 Later on, as the complication starts to emerge, the audiences will feel a stronger relationship with Jefferies. That even though Detective Thomas disagree with Jefferies's point of view on the murder and back it up with valid reasons and evidence, the audiences would still stay at Jefferies's side because they have been peeping through the window with him the whole time. The other conflict in the complication stage is when Stelle, Jefferies's nurse, shows up. During their conversation, Jefferies tell the audiences that he is not a suitable husband for Lisa because she is too perfect for him. Here Hitchcock is able to connect back to the woman on the magazines, now the audiences know she is Lisa. Which Lisa is standing by Jefferies's side because she also saw the scene with him. But this didn't remove the suspension from the audiences' hearts. In fact, this actually builds up more suspension since they want to know more about the lovers, and how would they work together to prove that Detective Thomas is wrong.
 Finally, in the climax, all these issues are resolved. Through the dialogue between Jefferies, Lisa, and Stella at 1:27:34, Hitchcock finally finishes developing Jefferies and Lisa's character. Their internal issues are solved when Lisa is willing to put herself in a dangerous situation, which is what Jefferies don't think she will do. Therefore, Jefferies changed his view towards Lisa. That he thinks Lisa is not some perfect human-being he can't touch, but rather a perfect wife for him. This shift of feeling closes the gap in between their hearts. Which after the tense and irritative scene of hide and seek, they finally stay together. All the other neighbors go on the good track, makes the audiences enter the state of denouement, and think everything is good, life is wonderful.

title: Rear Window Review
review: Rear Window is directed by Alfred Hitchcock and stars James Stewart, Thelma Ritter, and Grace Kelly. It follows L. B. Jeffries, a daredevil photographer (Stewart) with a broken leg who, confined to his apartment, passes the time by spying on his neighbors through the window. This grows to an obsession when he starts to think he may have discovered a little neighborhood murder. Stewart shines as Jeffries, providing insight into his thoughts and feelings with each and every reaction shot (of which there are dozens). The happenings outside the window are shown exclusively from Jeffries's point of view, both visually and audibly, and sometimes relies on his reaction to provide insight for the audience. The apartment-courtyard in which the majority of the action takes place serves to separate Jeffries from his surroundings by quite some distance. It is impressive, therefore, that the viewer is never confused about any of the essentially silent scenes that play out in the tiny windows opposite. In fact, it's almost impossible to not be pulled into each little drama that we see play out across the way, making Jeffries a surrogate for the audience's own particular brand of voyeurism. After all, what is a screen, if not a window into another life? And it is here that Stewarts co-stars come in, effectively pulling his and the audience's attention back inward. Ritter plays Jeffries's nurse, Stella, who provides him with a few pieces of sage wisdom. For example, "We've become a race of Peeping Toms. What people ought to do is get outside their own house and look in for a change." Although perhaps a bit on the nose, this line provides insight into what ties the film's many sometimes disparate small storylines together. Rear Window is ultimately about voyeurism as a vehicle for introspection. As earlier stated, Hitchcock uses Jeffries's reaction shots to help the audience interpret what he sees, but most of the time the reverse is just as true. Jeffries's interest is held by an attractive bachelorette and her suitors, a brokenhearted woman having dinner by herself, a newlywed couple, and another couple that does nothing but argue. We soon learn why these hold his attention: he is grappling with thoughts of his own potential marriage. His girlfriend, Lisa (Kelly) wants to tie the knot, but Jeffries is unconvinced that she could be happy while he is constantly travelling to dangerous places for his job. Jeffries's internal conflict supersedes all else in this film, with even the murder mystery sometimes feeling like a side storyline, a way for Lisa to prove herself to Jeffries. It's all just a way to tell Jeffries's internal story. At least, it is until the outside world finally comes crashing in, a full hour and 45 minutes into the runtime. Hitchcock is a master of suspense, and his skills are on full display here, ratcheting up the tension throughout the second act. It all builds to the unforgettable moment when a murderer stands silhouetted in Jeffries's doorway. Up until this moment, all of the action has occurred at a distance, with Jeffries nothing more than a spectator. For the first time he is unprotected by even a pane of glass, and the effect is substantial. By stretching the buildup to moments like this for as long as possible, Hitchcock keeps the audience constantly on the edge of their seats for almost the entire runtime. Ultimately, Hitchcock assembles all these parts, the love story, the murder mystery, and the artistic exercise of filming most of the movie from a distance, and combines them together with a remarkable cohesion thanks to the thematic through line of marriage and Stewart's excellent performance.

title: Masterful Information Abstraction
review: Rear Window is the story of a photographer named Jeff who is recovering from a broken leg and is grounded in his apartment until he is healed and can return to the field. Jeff is cared for by a nurse named Stella who aids Jeff is his recovery while also encouraging him to marry his girlfriend Lisa. Jeff is extremely reluctant to the idea as he describes that the two of them may not be compatible. The core of film revolves around his relationship conflicts with Lisa and eventually a suspected murder that took place in a neighboring apartment. The plot of the film is entirely driven from Jeff's immobile condition. The film's title is essential to the central cinematic theme of the film. That is, we watch an entire story unfold through a single scene of a rear window. In doing so, we see a carefully crafted story unfold just as Jeff does. The exposition of the film is overall quite limited. But it provides all of the elements needed to garner an audiences attention and curiosity. With consistent foreshadowing of trouble to come, the film invites the audience to join Jeff and look through his eyes. Rear Window is a masterwork display of information obfuscation and does so through a lens of voyeurism. Story telling in this nature is interesting because from a literary perspective it is the opposite of dramatic irony. Where dramatic irony is employed stories take on a certain sense of suspense where wonder what will happen to characters based on information we know but they do not. In Rear Window's case, the use of dramatic irony is entirely null and the result is suspense that imitates life. This version of suspense is far more real seeming because it is based off of information that is known and unknown. Much of story telling in film is done through the simple structure of an audience watching a story. Rear Window differs from this model going a level deeper. As an audience, we watch characters who view a story unfold. This distinction is important for the theme of voyeurism and for the layers of abstraction that are done through Jeff's apartment point of view. The information that we are given as audience members is given out when we are given point of view shots as if they were from Jeff's own eyes. The smooth camera movement from one apartment to the next throughout the film gives glimpses into the lives of his neighbors and gives us limited perspective on the happenings around him. This makes us speculate and draw our own conclusions in addition to the ones our characters creates. Rear Window is superb in its ability to simultaneously tell a story of suspected murder through what Jeff sees as well as intertwining the conflicts that he is facing is his relationship with Lisa. Rather than having a compartmentalized and divided story, the murder case acts as a cinematic element to push his relationship forward. Throughout the case Jeff sees Lisa differently and find a new appreciation for her. As mentioned earlier, the film uses point of view shots of Jeff's neighbors to further the murder plot and build suspense to the film. The characters that are found in the neighboring apartments also act to further his relationship with Lisa. Jeff often views scenes which include the likes of a newlywed couple and a lonely woman who drinks her sorrows away. Ultimately, it's shots of this nature that tell of an internal conflict within Jeff in which he is deciphering what is important to him and which life he would rather end up in.

title: A tad bit of analysis
review:
Although Rear Window is a relatively old film, I can see why it is one of the classics. In this film, L.B Jefferies is a photographer who is stuck in his room because of a leg injury. His only method of entertainment is to look out through his rear view window where he is able to peek into the lives of his neighbors. This simplistic setup of the story, however, doesn't dilute from the actual content of the story at all with elements of romance, mystery, and abundant amounts of suspense. Through his conversations with his caretaker Stella, his wife Lisa, and through his external action, we're able to slowly characterize and figure out what kind of person Jefferies is and discover the main conflicts of this film. We realize his dissatisfaction with Lisa and how he believes he is unable to decide whether or not to marry her. We also figure out the external conflict, which is revealed when he spent an entire night peering at Thorwald, concluded that he murdered his wife, and then almost obsessively trying to get his detective friend to go investigate. However, unlike other films, these conflicts are all resolved with Jefferies not having to move at all from his room. 
 Alfred Hitchcock, aka the Master of Suspense, lives up to his name in this film. By putting the audience in the point of view of L.B Jefferies he is able to masterfully create scenes of suspense where the user feels as restrained as the main protagonist of this story. Switching between the subjective point of view and the indirect-subjective point of view allows the audience to feel the emotions that are reflected in Jefferies' face. We can feel the anticipation and the suspense that Jefferies is feeling during a close up shot at his expression in the scene when Lisa becomes stuck in Thorwald's apartment; we realize his worthlessness and ours in the situation. We can feel the tense and almost hopeless situation as Thorwald slowly approaches towards his door and he frantically tries to find a weapon while being stuck in his wheelchair. Jefferies is kept in our attention to keep us anxious, the use of foreground framing keeps him that way even when he is moving about in the screen. When Thorwald finally appears in his room, the anticipation climaxes, as the camera depicts a low-angle shot of Thorwald, dominating over Jefferies. 
 Just like Jefferies, we are stuck behind a window, and can only view the events that are happening but unable to take action. This is shown throughout the film when Jefferies girlfriend takes a bold move and climbs into Thorwald's apartment, we feel a similar feeling to Jefferies: we felt fearful and wanted her to reconvene with us instead. However, just like Jefferies, we are not able to call out or stop her. Lisa is seen in the objective view, far away and distant from us. However, by using his camera, he is able to yet again zoom in to see what is going on and to also get closer to Lisa. Zooming in and out to view the different events that are happening in his neighborhood is a constant technique used throughout the film. Alfred Hitchcock likes to have the audience feel what the character is feeling and uses Jefferies' camera as a way to restrict our point of view but also to help us get in closer personally and to view more accurately what is happening.
Alfred Hitchcock uses of perspective also touches on a darker element of human nature: Voyeurism. Voyeurism is the act of deriving pleasure from spying on people engaging in intimate behaviors. Although it might not be sexual in nature, we do a similar activity by deriving pleasure from peeking into the lives of people in a movie theater. This is an element Hitchcock uses to entrap us into Jefferies' voyeuristic actions. We get to see many of his neighbors like "Miss Torso" who tends to be in revealing outfits and "Miss Lonelyhearts" who doesn't seem to be able to get an adequate boyfriend. We as the audience shares his curiosity, which eventually becomes obsessive, as the camera pans around to each window like he's watching a movie, we get to see a glimpse of their lives after each day. Alfred Hitchcock, however, doesn't provide any narration or explanation to what is happening. We as the audience have to deduce what is happening without any dialogue but only with the details that are given. This way of storytelling is part of the film's genius. It allows us to provide our own interpretations and secretly allows us to touch on our own voyeuristic tendencies. 
Rear Window unifies all these elements to become truly a classic and masterpiece. Alfred Hitchcock not only used a wide variety of film techniques but capitalized on them to capture the audience's attention and skillfully create scenes filled with suspense.

title: Rear Window is a great movie
review:
In the film Rear Window, main character Mr. Jeff has a broken leg with a cast on it, and he is watching all of his neighbors through the window of his tiny apartment. Even though the main character does not move out of his living place, the film is not boring at all because Jeff knows what is happening around him; what makes the beginning so interesting and attractive to me as an audience is I am able to experience what Mr. Jeff is watching. The window bridges the gap between character and audiences. In the beginning, there are many emotions on Jeff's face while he is watching the woman dancing, the man who is playing the piano, Mr. Thorwald and his wife, and etc. The camera shot goes back and forward between Jeff's face and the outside world. We can see how Jeff responses to each of the scenes through the moving camera. Director uses this technique to interact with audiences in order capture people's attentions. 
The background music is a significant factor that makes Rear Window a great film. The rhythm rises as the story rises to its climax. When the story starts, audience is focusing on what is going outside the window, the music brings nothing to audiences in the beginning. When the story keeps developing to its climax where Mr. Thorwald try to kill Jeff, cadence of the music goes rapidly fast, and it brings intension to audiences, it makes people nervous and curious about what is going to happen to Jeff. The music in this film really brings up the story together, and it also brings up audience's attention to plot developments through out. 
There is one thing stands out in the film which is the color combination in each scene. First of all, while Jeff is watching multiple actions happening in the neighbor, there are different colors in the frame. People dress up differently, and the bright colors correspond to the smile on Jeff's face because he is having fun with people's different lives. In addition, when Lisa Fremont comes to Jeff's apartment, she always dress up nicely; the color of her dress brings out the mood for their little date night and romantic time. Moreover, when Mr. Thorwald comes into Jeff's room, everything become so dark because there is no light. The scene creates scariness, and my heart rate increased as an audience because I was so nervous, I don't know what will happen but I want to know what will happen next. Color is an important factor in Rear Window, which makes it a successful film. 
After Mr. Jeff realizes something is wrong with Mrs. Thorwald, he uses the camera with a long lens in order to figure what is going on in Mr. Thorwald's apartment. Later on, he wants to get a more clear view to ensure his assumption that Mrs. Thorwald is gone; he takes out a telescope. And then, he is very sure about Mr. Thorwald has murdered his wife. The changing of Jeff's equipment corresponds to the plot developments too. Every little details in this film tie up together and leads to climax of the story. In addition, symbolism also plays out in Rear Window by the director. The dog died in the yard right after Jeff figured out Mrs. Thorwald has gone for so long. The dog symbolizes death, Jeff is right about that Mr. Thorwald had killed his wife, and he killed the dog too because the dog saw Mr. Thorwald is hiding something in his apartment. It also shows brutality of Mr. Thorwald.

title: One of Hitchcock's Best
review:
Rear Window is a great example of how to tell a visual story in an unconventional form. This film is one of the first, if not the first film to be created in a blatantly voyeuristic style. What makes Rear Window such a renowned classic is not what the story is, but how the story is told.

Most of the characters that we're introduced to are seen throughout the entire film and are mostly seen but not heard. They each add to the story in subtle ways and sometimes even relate to the thoughts and feelings of the main character Jefferies. Since the film is viewed mostly through his perspective, these thoughts and feelings are beamed into the viewer as well. The audience pieces the ongoing mystery together along with Jefferies. This gives the viewer an active role in the film. They aren't there just to consume, they're meant to feel like an active participant in solving the mystery presented. We're immobile in Jefferies' studio apartment, only able to see events unfold from the inside of his window. This perspective is never broken. Even though the the setting isn't physically dynamic, viewers get a sense of a larger and more vibrant environment by viewing the lives of the characters through their own apartment windows.

Everything feels incredibly deliberate, which is characteristic of a Hitchcock film. Every scene and every frame serves a purpose. This is definitely a film that benefits from multiple viewings. By picking up on small subtleties that arise from the secondary characters, you'll begin to notice how it all ties together.

The acting still holds up well in 2018. It doesn't feel very dated. The actors all do a great job and are generally convincing. James Stewart in particular does a stellar job in delivering facial expressions that fit the situation at hand. His acting really shines through in the more suspenseful parts of the film, where the terror on his face instills total dread for anyone who watches.

Hitchcock of course is known to be adept at suspense. Rear Window in particular has a few key scenes that keep you at the edge of your seat. These sequences are agonizingly drawn out, but not so much that they lose their effect. These scenes are paced very professionally and they leave much to the imagination. The scene just prior to the end of the film requires that the viewer suspends their disbelief to a significant amount which for some could ruin the moment. However, everything else about this scene is a great example of how to build suspense properly without overdoing it.

The last aspect of this film that sets it apart from others is how there are essentially two stories being told. Of course, there's the murder mystery aspect of this film and all the standard elements that go with it. The main character gets curious and starts investigating and eventually the perpetrator is exposed and brought to justice. However, this film could also be viewed as a romance. The relationship between Jefferies and Lisa is just as important In this film as the investigating that they take part in. The relationship between the two at the beginning of the film seems strained and awkward and Jefferies is convinced that they aren't fully compatible because of their differing lifestyles. As the film progresses and Lisa takes an interest in helping Jeff investigate the murder, they grow closer as a result. This aspect of the story is never neglected as Lisa does play a major role in the murder investigation as well. Her role becomes more active as the film gets closer to its end.

It's no mystery why Rear Window has the following that it does. Like other Hitchcock films, this one showcases an experimental approach to storytelling in a similar vein as Rope. It's creative risks like these that keep film fresh and diverse. Modern aspiring film-makers could learn a lot from Hitchcock's approach to film-making with its intricate design and clever use of visual elements.

9/10

title: REAR WINDOW REVIEW
review:
Elijah 8/20/18 Rear Window Review

If there is one director whose work will remain timeless and watchable in generations to come, it is Mr. Alfred Hitchcock. From the chilling story about a lowly man who's a little too obsessed with his mom (Psycho), to the story of a man struggling with his fear of heights (Vertigo), Mr. Hitchcock is a director that has earned respect and recognition from critics and fans all the way up until he sadly passed in 1980. But whenever I think about his films, there is always one that immediately comes to mind, Rear Window. If you haven't seen the film, then I recommend you to stop reading now, as I'm going to spoil everything that happens, but I URGE you to watch it if you haven't. With all that being said, let's get on with the review. The first thing you'll notice when the movie starts is how incredible the set design is. The panning camera shot showing all the people in this tiny apartment complex, from the rich musician, to the lonely women on the bottom floor, it really sets the tone of "coziness". We are then introduced to the film's main character, L.B. "Jeff" Jefferies, and we see that he's injured and so he's stuck in his apartment to spy on the neighbors, because this is 1954 and there wasn't really much to do back then. Now the basic story is that Jeff is injured and bored so he's spying on neighbors and eventually he becomes convinced that one of his neighbors, named Lars Thorwald, has murdered his wife. On the outset that sounds like every other thriller out there, but what makes Rear Window different is two specific things. First is that we never actually see any murder happen or even know if something did happen and it seems like the whole movie every character is telling him that nothing is wrong and that he's just bored or overly suspicious. We also realize very early on that Jeff is a pretty cynical person. We hear the conversation between him and his nurse where he says he doesn't want to marry his girlfriend Lisa Fremont, because she's too sophisticated or rich for him. The entire movie you are convinced that Thorwald didn't murder his wife and that Jeff is just bored and skeptical. That's why the eventual reveal that Thorwald did murder his wife is actually surprising! Because you watch the whole movie expecting the twist to be that he didn't murder his wife and Jeff is just way too suspicious and needs more sleep. But the twist is there is no twist! Which is actually genius because it preys on the fact that you usually expect a film like this to have a twist. The second thing that separates this film from other thriller films, is that the entire film takes place in his apartment. No really the ENTIRE film takes place in one apartment with Jeff and there isn't a single scene that breaks this. Even when Lisa is sneaking into Thorwald's apartment later in the movie, it's still from Jeff's point of view. We hear about stuff that happens outside of the apartment, but these never shown. This gives the film a very unique vibe that I haven't seen replicated since. These two attributes are the reasons why it has stood the test of time and is considered a classic. I haven't even mentioned the fantastic performances, particularly by James Stewart and Grace Kelly. The music by Franz Waxman is also soothing. What I like most about the music is that it only appears during character moments or scenes between Lisa and Jeff talking. There is no music whenever something intense or suspenseful is happening, which creates are very stressful atmosphere because it feels real. In the end, Rear Window is one of those rare movies where it truly feels unique even over 50 years later. It's a movie that has and will be appreciated and enjoyed for years to come.

9.5/10

title: RW
review:
Rear Window
From an artistic perspective, I thought that this movie was very well done. The colors were vibrant but also showed the dullness that living in an urban environment can have. I also enjoyed the costumes and makeup of all the actors. I found that it reflected the time period well and accurately represented what a middle class person would dress and look like. I also enjoyed the sounds that were incorporated into the film. Throughout the film, birds could be heard or dogs barking and this gave a very open feel to the otherwise closed in feeling of being in a walled in apartment complex. Another very good aspect of the film was the quality of the actors. Throughout the movie, the actors do a very good job of "show don't tell." What I mean by this is that many scenes in the movie do not need the actors telling each other how they feel and it can be read on their faces. An example of this is when Grace comes to the realization that LB's theory that Lars killed his wife may have some truth behind it. You can see the change of expression on her face and without her even saying anything, the audience knows what she is thinking. The film had a very slow and relaxing feel at the beginning which I found interesting because it would be the opposite of what you might feel living in a downtown apartment. At the beginning of the film, the camera pans from apartment to apartment showing the daily lives of the people around LB. This gives us the feeling that we are actually looking through LB's eyes and feeling what he feels. I had a slight sense of loneliness when watching this because I felt that all of this was going on around me but I still felt distant and not a part of it all. I believe this is what Hitchcock was intending when filming this because it allows us to relate more to LB. During this scene, and in many other parts of the movie, it is as if LB is actually in a movie theater watching all of this unfold in front of him. In many scenes, such as the one where Grace breaks into Lars' house, LB must sit back helpless and watch it all take place as with the audience in the theater or the viewers at home. I found this very unique in that I have never experienced this perspective with any other movie I had seen. One thing about the film that can be seen as both a positive and a negative is the fact that there is a very long buildup from the beginning of the film to the climax. Although this can be seen as very important aspect of the story, I found it kind of boring at times and a little slow. There were times that I found myself spacing out and losing focus in the film. While I believe that a large portion of the film was slow, the last half hour of the movie had me on the edge of my seat. When Grace broke into the apartment and when Lars confronted LB were very well done. I felt the suspense that LB felt because we both felt that we were helpless and trapped in our seats.

title: Fantastic film
review:
Rear Window was a wonderful movie that more than fits into Hitchcock's portfolio of masterpieces.

Personally I have trouble categorizing this movie into a single genre as it is so diverse. With this said this movie certainly used certain elements from multiple genres. One of these genres that the film certainly borrowed from was film noir. One of the biggest conflicts of the film was whether or not Thorwald killed his wife. Even I as a viewer was unsure if this was the case while I was watching it. Although Rear Window's setting might've been too trusting and almost lush for it to be considered hard boiled, this movie certainly was a crime drama with certain romantic elements. Additionally this movie has many elements of a suspense film. I know personally I was sitting on the edge of my seat while Lisa was going into Thorwald's apartment, as well as when Thorwald had entered Jeff's. However I personally don't believe there was enough suspense throughout the entire movie for it to be outright considered a full-out thriller movie.

Alfred Hitchcock claimed to be a formalist director at heart and that really showed in the film. The movie used continuity editing so that it was easy for the viewer to sympathize with the protagonist, where as if he used non-continuity here the viewer might get confused and might emotionally disconnect from the protagonist. Additionally at the beginning of the movie and at the end of the movie the pacing of the cuts is very slow to show that there is very little tension. At the climax of the film the pacing is much faster to express a new sense of urgency and tension.

The shots used in the film and the camera techniques were unlike many other movies. This first scene in this film was a long panning shot of Jeff's backyard showing off a unique assortment of happy individuals from both in and outside their apartments. I think this opening shot really impressed me because this scene not only conveyed who many of the individual characters and families in this neighborhood were, but it also did a really good job of making this neighborhood seem especially open and trusting. One of the major plot points of this movie is that the protagonist, Jeff, is looking at his neighbors through their apartment windows. To compliment this most of the shots in the film, were framed by Jeff's window sill. Like I said before the viewer throughout the film felt like they were watching from Jeff's point of view, where they could see what was happening around them but they were stuck in their seats and unable to affect anything. Hitchcock was able to build this sympathy also by showing an event happening outside of the window and then showing a close up on one of the protagonists so that they know how to feel about these events.

This film also focused in on the certain themes and successfully raised a lot of questions about them throughout it. One of the themes that was brought up was community. At the beginning of the movie, the neighborhood that Jeff lived in was portrayed as being, perhaps a bit more friendly than most but overall unextraordinary. You felt like if you knew any one of those neighbors you'd be friends with them. But later in the film, obviously this sense of community is betrayed as one of the neighbors finds their dog strangled to death. Hitchcock often leaves his audience afraid of things people have come to trust in his films like in his other classic, the birds. Additionally this movie seems to revolve around Voyeurism which in this case is the pleasure one gets from watching people who don't know that they are being watched. This movie shows both positive and negative outcomes from Jeff's "peeping" so the question is left up in the air. However some viewers got a sense that the voyeurism Hitchcock was referring to wasn't staring at unsuspecting people through a window, but rather staring at characters through a movie.

All in all I was absolutely in love with the cinematography and am looking forward to watching the rest of Hitchcock's films.

title: Rear Window Review
review:
The 1954 film Rear Window, encompasses the story of L.B. 'Jeff' Jeffries, played by James Stewart, a wheelchair-bound photographer who is injured after a racetrack accident. In his post-recovery, Jeff is confined to his apartment, leading him to watch his neighbors through his "rear window." As a result, Jeff finds alarming discoveries about his neighbors, revealing more about the "ordinary" town.

The film begins with the audience's introduction to Jeff, the protagonist of the movie. After an accident, Jeff is bound to a wheelchair and begins to watch his neighbors through his courtyard apartment. As the story progresses, the audience is introduced to various characters of town. Jeff starts to memorize the patterns of each of his neighbors, understanding their day-to-day life and responsibilities. In addition, the audience is introduced to Stella, Jeff's nurse, and Lisa, Jeff's "fiancé." The film shifts after Jeff makes a shocking discovery about the Thorwalds, a couple who lives directly across from Jeff. After previously observing the Thorwalds' complicated relationship with each other, Jeff notices Mrs. Thorwald's disappearance. As Mr. Thorwald becomes increasingly more mysterious and shady, Jeff recruits help from Doyle, a police officer as well as Stella and Lisa. The story progresses, and Jeff develops his theory on Mrs. Thorwald's murder and seeks evidence to affirm his guilt. At the end of the film, Mr. Thorwald's guilt is confirmed when he confronts Jeff, ultimately leading to a fight. As a result, Mr. Thorwald is arrested and faces the repercussions of his actions.

Throughout the film, Hitchcock's specific presentation of characters and context adds to the genre of suspense. The audience's ability to grasp the complexity of each character without any dialogue or direct involvement with the main character plays a significant role in establishing suspense. Mr. Thorwald's anonymity to the audience enhances the level of suspense and mystery, as Jeff tries to confirm Mr. Thorwald's guilt in his wife's murder. In addition, I noticed the use of music and time in the film. In more intense scenes, Hitchcock incorporates a darker aesthetic and eerie music, dramatizing the feelings of suspense. This is evident in Director Hitchcock's decisions to have most of the suspenseful moments occur at night. Some of these scenes included Lisa's search of Mr. Thorwald's apartment, the dog's murder, and the confrontation between Mr. Thorwald and Jeff that occurred at the end of the film. In addition, I found it interesting that the entirety of the film took place in Jeff's apartment and was still able to omit a dynamic, thrilling feeling as the audience watches the film. In some cases, filming in one location can negate natural progression and make a movie feel slow.

Apart from the shocking plot revelations and the suspenseful scenes, Hitchcock's incorporation of unique camera perspectives and angles demonstrates a unique way to translate film. The utilization of the "three-part POV" and intense zoom-ins, allow Hitchcock to reinvent film in a new, meaningful way. One example of this is Hitchcock's camera angle after Lisa starts to believe Jeff's accusations. The camera zooms in from a lower angle, increasingly getting higher as it zooms closer to Lisa's frightened facial expression. In contrast, this is evident in Hitchcock's decision to incorporate a broader camera angle during intense moments. While Lisa is attempting to collect evidence from Mr. Thorwald's apartment, "Miss Lonelyhearts" attempts suicide simultaneously. In this shot, Hitchcock intensifies the thrilling emotion by closing the blinds in Miss Lonelyhearts' apartment, giving the audience feelings of uncertainty about her fate; all occurring while Lisa is searching Mr. Thorwald's apartment. Since there are several things transpiring, Hitchcock uses a broader camera angle in displaying the content of this scene.

title: Peeping Tom and a Bombshell Blonde
review:
Doyle! I think my neighbor across the courtyard murder his wife! What evidence do I have? I can answer that for Jefferies - a dead dog and a purse. 
When it comes to being the best amatuer detective in the block, Jeffries is the first thing that comes to mind, if you need someone to watch your neighbor day in and day out, he is your guy. 
Jeff (James Stewart) also known as L.B. Jefferies. An amazing photographer turned sleuth when he breaks his leg getting into the middle of a racetrack to take a picture. Stuck in a full leg cast and bound to a wheelchair for several weeks, Jeff finds many ways to entertain himself, like scratching itches on his leg, taking pictures of others while they are unaware, and also watching those same people. He watches his neighbors argue, a pianist play his music, a dancer dance in her underwear, a newlywed couple moving in, and a husband taking care of his bedridden wife. He gets the occasional visit from his nurse/caretaker Stella (Thelma Ritter) a sassy older woman who is a hard worker and tries to convince Jefferies that watching his neighbors is pretty creepy, but he still continues to do so. Stella also talks to Jeff about his girlfriend, Lisa (Grace Kelly) a fashionista socialite, who Stella believes is just the right girl for Jeff and is very much in love with him and that Jeff should marry her. However, Jeff believes he has too much of a rough and tough lifestyle, where you can only have one suitcase, and that's not the life he would want to give Lisa. Sorry to break it to you Jefferies, but Lisa isn't the only one who can change themself *cough Jefferies cough*. Moving on in the movie, we see Jefferies neighbor, Mr. Thorwald (Raymond Burr) across the way acting somewhat somewhat suspicious one night, and Jefferies decides to make Thorwald his next person to peep on, after the girl who dances in her underwear everyday. Jefferies then uses his old timey war connections to get his friend Detective Doyle (Wendell Corey) to help him with this case, even though Doyle does not see much of a case, he still entertains Jefferies by checking out Mr. Thorwald and his suspicious behavior, while our peeping tom continues to peep his eyes away. After seeing other suspicious behavior from Mr. Thorwald like wrapping up large knives, packing up all of his wife's belongings, wrapping up his mattress, and the straw that broke the camel's back (or should we say Jefferies leg) a dead dog near Mr. Thorwald's garden. After noticing this Jefferies decides to send his small army of Lisa and Stella to harass Mr.Thorwald and snoop around to find some hard and tangible evidence. During this time Lisa sees an opportunity to sneak into Mr. Thorwald's home to grab some more hard evidence, and she does it alone because she's a risk taker. In the end, Lisa almost gets assaulted, gets arrested, but gets out of jail in the end. Mr. Thorwald realizes that Jefferies has been watching him the whole time, and decides to give Jefferies what he deserves, after all he is a peeping tom. In the end Mr. Thorwald confesses to murdering his wife and everyone lives happily ever after. 
This movie is filled a lot of suspense but not a lot of twists and turns. This movie didn't really wow me, it was good, but not the best movie I have ever seen. When I hear the name Alfred Hitchcock I expect a lot and I was kind of disappointed. This movie came of to me as a peeping tom who gets caught up in something bigger than him, but it alls works out in his favor. His girlfriend has to change herself (unknowingly) so that in the end he realizes she's the one and he's ready to settle down. Maybe it's because I'm from a different generation, but this movie did not really have me on the edge of my seat, it had me laughing. All the cliches of movies from that era shined through, and I think Hitchcock could have done better.
